question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
The number
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ\]is expressed in the form $r \, \text{cis } \theta$, where $r > 0$ and $0^\circ \le \theta < 360^\circ$.  Find $\theta$ in degrees.
inference:
Let
\[S = \text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ.\]Then
\[S \text{cis } 8^\circ = \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \text{cis } 99^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 155^\circ.\]Subtracting these equations, we get
\[S - S \text{cis } 8^\circ = \text{cis } 75^\circ - \text{cis } 155^\circ.\]Then
\[S (1 - \text{cis } 8^\circ) = \text{cis } 75^\circ - \text{cis } 155^\circ = \text{cis } 75^\circ - \text{cis } (180^\circ - 75^\circ) = \text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } (-75^\circ) = 2 \cos 75^\circ.\]Hence,
\[S = \frac{2 \cos 75^\circ}{1 - \text{cis } 8^\circ} = \frac{2 \cos 75^\circ}{1 - \cos 8^\circ - i \sin 8^\circ}.\]To get rid of the complex number in the denominator, we multiply the numerator and denominator by the conjugate of the denominator:
\[S = \frac{2 \cos 75^\circ (1 - \cos 8^\circ + i \sin 8^\circ)}{(1 - \cos 8^\circ)^2 + \sin^2 8^\circ} = \frac{2 \cos 75^\circ (1 - \cos 8^\circ + i \sin 8^\circ)}{2 - 2 \cos 8^\circ}.\]This simplifies to
\[S = \frac{\cos 75^\circ (1 - \cos 8^\circ + i \sin 8^\circ)}{1 - \cos 8^\circ}.\]Since $1 - \cos 8^\circ$ is positive, the argument of $S$ is $\boxed{8^\circ}.$
ground_truth:
First, we note that the angle measures form an arithmetic sequence whose average is $111^\circ$.

We have that
\begin{align*}
&\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ  \\
&= \frac{\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ}{\text{cis } 111^\circ} \cdot \text{cis } 111^\circ \\
&= [\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)] \text{cis } 111^\circ.
\end{align*}The terms of the sum
\[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]can be paired into terms of the form $\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ$, and
\begin{align*}
\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ &= \cos n^\circ + i \sin n^\circ + \cos n^\circ - i \sin n^\circ \\
&= 2 \cos n^\circ,
\end{align*}which is real.  Therefore,
\[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]is real.  Let
\[r = \text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ).\]Then
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ = r \, \text{cis } 111^\circ,\]so $\theta = \boxed{111^\circ}$.

question:
Let
\[S = \text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ.\]Then
\[S \text{cis } 8^\circ = \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \text{cis } 99^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 155^\circ.\]Subtracting these equations, we get
\[S - S \text{cis } 8^\circ = \text{cis } 75^\circ - \text{cis } 155^\circ.\]Then
\[S (1 - \text{cis } 8^\circ) = \text{cis } 75^\circ - \text{cis } 155^\circ = \text{cis } 75^\circ - \text{cis } (180^\circ - 75^\circ) = \text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } (-75^\circ) = 2 \cos 75^\circ.\]Hence,
\[S = \frac{2 \cos 75^\circ}{1 - \text{cis } 8^\circ} = \frac{2 \cos 75^\circ}{1 - \cos 8^\circ - i \sin 8^\circ}.\]To get rid of the complex number in the denominator, we multiply the numerator and denominator by the conjugate of the denominator:
\[S = \frac{2 \cos 75^\circ (1 - \cos 8^\circ + i \sin 8^\circ)}{(1 - \cos 8^\circ)^2 + \sin^2 8^\circ} = \frac{2 \cos 75^\circ (1 - \cos 8^\circ + i \sin 8^\circ)}{2 - 2 \cos 8^\circ}.\]This simplifies to
\[S = \frac{\cos 75^\circ (1 - \cos 8^\circ + i \sin 8^\circ)}{1 - \cos 8^\circ}.\]Since $1 - \cos 8^\circ$ is positive, the argument of $S$ is $\boxed{8^\circ}.$

inference: The solution is correct.  The argument of $S$ is indeed $\boxed{8^\circ}$.

We have that
\begin{align*}
&\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ  \\
&= \frac{\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ}{\text{cis } 111^\circ} \cdot \text{cis } 111^\circ \\
&= [\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)] \text{cis } 111^\circ.
\end{align*}The terms of the sum
\[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]can be paired into terms of the form $\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ$, and
\begin{align*}
\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ &= \cos n^\circ + i \sin n^\circ + \cos n^\circ - i \sin n^\circ \\
&= 2 \cos n^\circ,
\end{align*}which is real.  Therefore,
\[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]is real.  Let
\[r = \text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ).\]Then
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ = r \, \text{cis } 111^\circ,\]so $\theta = \boxed{111^\circ}$.
